data.title: Screen time prevalent under grandparents' care, study finds
data.description: When Grandma and Grandpa are in charge, the children are likely staring at a screen—a long-standing parental complaint now supported by University of Arizona research.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Space traffic and trash: Policy experts work toward a sustainable final frontier
data.description: In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik. Several months later, the U.S. sent Explorer I into space. With two small objects, the space race began.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Magnetic fields can map the universe—here's how
data.description: Who knew that magnetic fields could be so useful? Astronomers are able to use magnetic fields to map our environment within the Milky Way using a technique called Faraday rotation.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Looking to the Pacific, scientists improve forecasts of atmospheric rivers
data.description: As atmospheric rivers pounded the U.S. West Coast last winter, scientists deployed increasingly advanced observing tools over the Pacific Ocean to improve forecasts of the powerful storms.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Measles has long-term health consequences for kids. Vaccines can prevent all of them.
data.description: Measles can erase the immune system's "memory" and cause a rare but fatal health condition. The MMR vaccine prevents these repercussions, evidence shows.
data.source: Live Science: The Most Interesting Articles

data.title: Hard carbon-tin nano-composite creates high-performance battery anode
data.description: As the demand continues to grow for batteries capable of ultra-fast charging and high energy density in various sectors—from electric vehicles to large-scale energy storage systems (ESS)—a joint research team from POSTECH (Pohang University of Science and Technology) and the Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) has developed a promising next-generation anode material that may address these critical needs. The research is published in the journal ACS Nano.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Hubble spies a cosmic pillar in the Eagle Nebula
data.description: In anticipation of the upcoming 35th anniversary of the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, ESA/Hubble is continuing the celebrations with a new view of the Eagle Nebula. This vast stellar nursery displays a towering spire of cosmic gas and dust that incorporates new data processing techniques developed since an image of this region was last released two decades ago.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Discovery of biosignatures in K2-18b - Sanskriti IAS
data.description: Discovery of biosignatures in K2-18b  Sanskriti IASपृथ्वी के अलावा और कहां है जीवन?  BBC...तो यहां रहते हैं एलियन? इस ग्रह पर छिपा है राज, वैज्ञानिकों ने ढूंढ निकाला सबूत  News18 Hindi...
data.source: Google News Science IN (HI)

data.title: Environmental variability promotes the evolution of cooperation among humans, simulation suggests
data.description: Researchers at the University of Tsukuba have demonstrated that intensified environmental variability (EV) can promote the evolution of cooperation through simulation based on evolutionary game theory.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Disrupting 'communication' with plants could limit cyst nematode infections
data.description: Targeting a newly discovered vulnerability in the signals that cyst nematodes use to infect plant roots could be a powerful method for reducing the damage the parasitic worms cause in crops such as soybeans, according to a study co-authored by an Iowa State University professor.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Native American names extend the earthquake history of northeastern North America
data.description: In 1638, an earthquake in what is now New Hampshire and Plymouth, Massachusetts, left colonists stumbling from the strong shaking and water sloshing out of the pots used by Native Americans to cook a midday meal along the St. Lawrence River, according to contemporaneous reports.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Discovering 'pirate parasitism': Wasps can successfully exploit unsuitable hosts with help from another species
data.description: Parasitoid wasps sometimes lay eggs in unsuitable host insects, a behavior that has traditionally been considered accidental. However, researchers at the University of Tsukuba have discovered that parasitism can still be successful in these cases—if another species of wasp lays eggs in the same host simultaneously. They have named this newly discovered parasitic strategy "pirate parasitism."
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Indigenous Peoples feel the brunt of rising temperatures, climate policy
data.description: In the subarctic and arctic reaches of the Northwest Territories (NWT), the climate is warming faster than most other places on the planet. Decades before scientists and governments were grasping the threats of rising temperatures amid public debate over climate policies, Indigenous Peoples in the region were sounding the alarm.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Image: Hubble spots a squid in the whale
data.description: Today's rather aquatic-themed NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features the spiral galaxy Messier 77, also known as the Squid Galaxy, which sits 45 million light-years away in the constellation Cetus (The Whale).
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Lake deposits reveal directional shaking during devastating 1976 Guatemala earthquake
data.description: Sediment cores drawn from four lakes in Guatemala record the distinct direction that ground shaking traveled during a 1976 magnitude 7.5 earthquake that devastated the country, according to researchers at the Seismological Society of America's Annual Meeting.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Analyzing extracurricular activities in college admissions process to improve access
data.description: In recent years, discussions about inequality in the college admissions process have focused on the use of standardized tests like the SAT. But few discussions have focused on another important part of the college application: the listing of extracurricular activities.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Regulators of DNA folding could be targets for treating cancer
data.description: Most cells in the human body each contain about six feet of DNA. Yet the nucleus, where DNA is coiled, is no larger than a single speck of dust. Despite its density, DNA is not a tangled ball of yarn. It is organized into intricate layers of loops that fold and unfold in response to cues from the cell.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Q&A: How scientists and farmers are working to adapt to avian flu
data.description: The avian flu virus continues to affect poultry producers and dairy farms in 2025. In North Carolina alone, the virus has resulted in the loss of millions of birds on poultry farms. Meanwhile, less than a year after avian flu was first detected in dairy herds, a new strain of the virus has been found in Nevada cows.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Researchers discover new plant species Saussurea degeensis from southwestern China
data.description: Saussurea is one of the largest and most rapidly evolving genera within the Asteraceae family, comprising approximately 520 species found in the Northern Hemisphere. These species display remarkable diversity in their morphologies and preferred habitats.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Red, pink or white, all roses were once yellow says genomic analysis
data.description: Red roses, the symbol of love, were likely yellow in the past, indicates a large genomic analysis by researchers from Beijing Forestry University, China. Roses of all colors, including white, red, pink, and peach, belong to the genus Rosa, which is a member of the Rosaceae family.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Price discrimination is getting smarter—and low-income consumers are paying the price
data.description: For customers who don't have the freedom to choose where they shop, technological advancements—particularly artificial intelligence (AI) and intrusive personal data collection—are making price discrimination, inflation and lower-quality goods increasingly likely. Vulnerable consumers are most at risk.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Heavy metals taint nearly 1 in 6 croplands worldwide, say scientists
data.description: Nearly 17% of the world's croplands are contaminated with "heavy metals," according to a new study in Science. These contaminants—arsenic, cadmium, lead, and others—may be invisible to the eye, but they threaten food safety and human health.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: NASA balloon at float, begins Southern Hemisphere journey
data.description: The first super pressure balloon flight of NASA's New Zealand Balloon Campaign reached its float altitude after lifting off from Wānaka Airport, New Zealand, at 10:44 a.m. NZST, Thursday, April 17 (6:44 p.m., Wednesday, April 16 in U.S. Eastern Time). The football-stadium-sized, heavy-lift super pressure balloon is on a mission planned for 100 days or more around the Southern Hemisphere's mid-latitudes.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: How to catch the shooting stars of spring's first meteor shower, the Lyrids
data.description: When the Lyrid meteor shower reaches its peak, it will be spring's first chance to see shooting stars.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Precision-shaped Cu₂O crystals unlock new potential for clean energy catalysts
data.description: Can the shape of a crystal really change how well it performs in clean energy technology? A new study says yes—decisively.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
